content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player with the characteristics described, I would choose to play this game strategically while aiming for a secure and predictable outcome. Given the payoff structure, it appears that choosing B is more beneficial if my anonymous opponent consistently chooses R (since I get 35$ each time instead of 0$). However, since there are 75 rounds, and I am not guaranteed that my opponent will always choose R, I would consider a mixed strategy.

In a mixed strategy game, players make choices randomly according to specific probabilities. If I assume that my opponent is also rational and cautious, they might adopt a similar approach. In this case, I could use a simple strategy: pick R with a probability of 1/3 and pick B with a probability of 2/3 in each round. This way, I give myself a higher chance of getting the more secure outcome (40$ per round) while still having a reasonable chance of getting 35$ if my opponent picks R.

Over the course of 75 rounds, this strategy would result in an average payoff of approximately 40.67$ per round, which is slightly better than the outcome of always picking B (40$). While this might not be the optimal strategy under certain conditions, as a cautious player aiming for predictability and security, I find this approach suitable given my personality and preferences.

{B} (since I will primarily choose B using the mixed strategy described above)
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

Since both of us picked B in the previous round, we received 40$ each as our payoff. In the next round, I will maintain my mixed strategy and continue to pick R with a probability of 1/3 and pick B with a probability of 2/3. If my opponent also sticks to their rationality and chooses a similar mixed strategy, it is still possible that we may both pick R in subsequent rounds and get the higher payoff of 45$.

However, it is important to note that I cannot predict my opponent's exact strategy since they are anonymous. All I can do is assume they will act rationally and cautious like myself. If, for example, my opponent decides to always pick R in an attempt to maximize their earnings, then my mixed strategy might not be optimal anymore.

In this next round, I will pick B as per the mixed strategy described before.
